tasks.title: Make Post Detection Robust
tasks.description: Current post detection is fragile - hardcoded "[BitBot] MonetizationVars" string that ignores config and breaks if title changes. Need reliable way to identify bot's own posts.
tasks.details:
Current Issues:
- Hardcoded post_identifier = "[BitBot] MonetizationVars" in helpers.py
- Ignores config["reddit"]["postIdentifier"] 
- Only uses title.startswith() - fragile
- No fallback if title format changes

Proposed Solution (Hybrid Approach):
1. Store post IDs in bot_state.json
   - Add "allPostIds": [] to track all bot posts
   - Save post ID when creating/updating posts
   
2. Detection logic:
   - Primary: Check if post.id in bot_state["allPostIds"]
   - Fallback: Check author == bot_user AND title.startswith(config identifier)
   - Self-healing: Add discovered posts to state
   
3. Use config postIdentifier instead of hardcoded string

Benefits:
- Survives title format changes
- Self-healing if state lost
- Respects configuration
- No mod permissions needed

Files to modify:
- src/helpers.py: get_bot_posts() function
- src/models.py: Add allPostIds to BotState
- src/post_to_reddit.py: Save post IDs after creation

tasks.title: Clarify Rolling Update Changelog Behavior
tasks.description: Clarify behavior of changelog vs available list in rolling update mode. Need to decide how to display cumulative changes over 7-day update window.
tasks.details:
Current Behavior:
- Changelog: Shows Added/Updated/Removed in current update
- Available List: Shows table of all apps with latest versions

Question for Rolling Update Mode:
When updating same post for 7 days, what should changelog show?

Option A: Cumulative (all changes over 7 days)
- Day 0: "Added BitLife v1.0"
- Day 2: Post shows "Added BitLife v1.0" + "Added BitLife Go v2.0"
- Day 4: Post shows all 3 changes

Option B: Latest Only
- Only show most recent change
- Simpler but loses history

Option C: Keep Both Sections
- Changelog = recent changes
- Available List = full inventory
- Current behavior, just clarify purpose

Decision Needed:
- Which option fits user workflow?
- Should changelog accumulate or replace?
- Is available list redundant with changelog?

Files affected:
- src/post_to_reddit.py: _generate_changelog(), _generate_post_body()
- templates/post_template.md: Post structure

tasks.title: Refactor to Modular Architecture
tasks.description: Refactor codebase into proper modular structure. Break up god modules (helpers.py 385 LOC, post_to_reddit.py 358 LOC) into focused, reusable components organized by domain.
tasks.details:
Current Problems:
- helpers.py: 385 LOC, 7 responsibilities (god module)
- post_to_reddit.py: 358 LOC, complex logic
- release_manager.py: 266 LOC, mixed concerns
- No clear separation of domains
- Hard to test, hard to maintain

Proposed Structure:

src/
├── core/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── config.py          - load_config() from helpers.py
│   ├── state.py           - State management (bot_state, release_state)
│   └── credentials.py     - Credentials class from helpers.py
│
├── reddit/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── client.py          - init_reddit() from helpers.py
│   ├── posts.py           - get_bot_posts(), update_older_posts()
│   └── parser.py          - parse_versions_from_post()
│
├── github/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── releases.py        - get_github_data(), get_source_releases()
│   └── parser.py          - parse_release_notes(), parse_release_description()
│
├── scripts/
│   ├── check_comments.py  - Refactored to use core/reddit
│   ├── post_to_reddit.py  - Refactored to use core/reddit
│   ├── release_manager.py - Refactored to use core/github
│   └── ... (other scripts)
│
└── models.py              - Keep as-is (Pydantic models)
└── paths.py               - Keep as-is (path constants)
└── patch_file.py          - Keep as-is (standalone utility)

Migration Plan:
1. Create new directory structure
2. Extract functions from helpers.py into core/
3. Extract Reddit logic into reddit/
4. Extract GitHub logic into github/
5. Update imports in all scripts
6. Update tests
7. Delete old helpers.py

Target Metrics:
- Max file size: 150 LOC
- Single responsibility per module
- Clear domain boundaries
- 100% test coverage maintained

Benefits:
- Easier to understand
- Easier to test (mock specific modules)
- Easier to extend
- Follows Single Responsibility Principle
- Reduces coupling

tasks.title: Split Remaining Large Scripts
tasks.description: Split remaining large scripts into smaller, focused modules. post_to_reddit.py (355 LOC), release_manager.py (268 LOC), and patch_file.py (172 LOC) are still too large and violate Single Responsibility Principle.
tasks.details:
Current Large Scripts:
1. post_to_reddit.py - 355 LOC
   - Title generation
   - Changelog generation
   - Available list generation
   - Post body generation
   - Post creation
   - Rolling update logic
   - Main orchestration

2. release_manager.py - 268 LOC
   - GitHub API calls
   - Release fetching
   - Release parsing
   - Asset downloading
   - File patching
   - Release creation
   - Main orchestration

3. patch_file.py - 172 LOC
   - Key obfuscation
   - XOR encoding/decoding
   - Encryption/decryption
   - Data modification
   - Main orchestration

Proposed Refactoring:

post_to_reddit.py → reddit/posting/
├── title_generator.py - _generate_dynamic_title()
├── changelog.py - _generate_changelog()
├── body_builder.py - _generate_post_body(), _generate_available_list()
├── poster.py - _post_new_release()
└── main.py - Orchestration only (~50 LOC)

release_manager.py → gh/releases/
├── fetcher.py - get_source_releases(), get_github_data()
├── parser.py - parse_release_description() (merge with existing)
├── downloader.py - download_asset()
├── patcher.py - patch_file()
├── creator.py - create_bot_release()
└── main.py - Orchestration only (~50 LOC)

patch_file.py → crypto/
├── obfuscation.py - get_obfuscated_key()
├── encoding.py - xor_and_b64_encode(), b64_decode_and_xor()
├── cipher.py - encrypt(), decrypt()
├── modifier.py - modify()
└── main.py - Orchestration only (~30 LOC)

Target Metrics:
- Max file size: 100 LOC
- Single responsibility per module
- Clear function grouping
- Easier to test individual components

Benefits:
- Smaller, focused modules
- Easier to understand
- Easier to test (mock specific components)
- Easier to maintain
- Follows Single Responsibility Principle
